h1.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

span.span:

div.h1: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.p: This paper studies the effect of preload treatment on the elastic modulus of braided high modulus polyethylene (HMPE) rope for static loading in tendon-driven robot. Two different methods of preload treatment were applied on HMPPE rope namely preload in tensile and cyclic loadings. A suitable load level of preload treatment was also investigated in order to apply in the real application. Furthermore, the cause of the lowest elastic modulus of the stabilized rope was identified by performing preload treatment on the strand constituting the rope. After completing preload treatment, the preloaded rope and strand were tested in five cyclic loadings further in order to examine the stability of rope modulus. To detect the change in construction geometry of the rope during preload treatment and cyclic loading of preloaded rope in term of rope diameter and strand angle, acoustic emission (AE) testing and a high speed camera were used. Results show that preload treatment in tensile loading could be conducted as an alternative method to replace the preload treatment in cyclic loading which is commonly used. It is also found that elastic modulus of the preloaded rope and strand at the first cycle have smallest value compared to the other cycles (cycles 2â5). This phenomenon is caused by elastic recovery of the material itself which could occur after preload treatment.
Keywords:

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

h3.p:
Table 1.
Guidelines of preload treatment on synthetic fiber rope.

div.p:
Recently, synthetic fiber ropes with small size in diameter have emerged as potential materials to utilize in the robotic fields, for example, active endoscope, artificial muscle and tendon-driven (Horigome etÂ al.,
2014
; Kitano etÂ al.,
2013
; Kozuki etÂ al.,
2014
; Mazumdar etÂ al.,
2017
; Wakimoto etÂ al.,
2009
). In these fields, in order to control the robotics properly, a stabilization of the longitudinal elastic modulus of the rope is essential.

Therefore, the aims of this paper are (1) to differentiate the preload treatment in cyclic loading and tensile loading, (2) to examine the suitable % MBL in preload treatment, and (3) to investigate why the first loading of fully stabilized rope behaves as viscous material.

In this study, we prepared high modulus polyethylene (HMPE) rope as specimens. The HMPE rope was constructed by a braiding method using eight strands. Each strand was made from parallel fibers. Both ropes and strands were purchased from Hayami (Hayami Industry Co., LTD, Japan). The minimum break load (MBL) of the strand and rope were 430âN and 1900âN, respectively. The MBL for the strand was experimentally determined, and the MBL for the rope was obtained by the manufacturer. Linear density, expressed in grams per kilometer (tex = 1g/1âkm) is commonly used in textile engineering field due to the presence of voids in the rope. In this study, the linear density of the strand and rope were determined by cutting the strand and rope at a length of 105âmm and weighted them by electronic balance (Shimadzu AX200).
Figure 1
shows the braided HMPE rope consisting of eight strands and
Table 2
summarizes the material properties of both the strand and rope.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

div.p:
Figure 1.
Braided HMPE rope composed of eight strands.

Figure 1.
Braided HMPE rope composed of eight strands.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

h3.p:
Table 2.
Properties of strand and braided HMPE rope.

div.p:
In this study, preload treatment on the rope was performed in two methods in order to investigate their effects on rope modulus. The first method was in cyclic loading and the second was in tensile loading. To clarify the cause of the smallest rope modulus at the first cyclic loading of the stabilized rope, preload treatment on the strand was performed as well. Since strand was produced from parallel fibers and there is no effect of construction geometry on its modulus, though the material itself does. The preload treatment conditions of rope and strand are illustrated in
Table 3
. Preload treatment in tensile loading of rope and strand were carried out at 20 and 30% MBL then hold at these loading levels for 3600s. The preload treatment in cyclic loading of the rope was conducted at the maximum load level of 20%MBL for 10 cycles whereas the preload treatment of strand was carried out at the maximum load level of 20, 50, and 70%MBL for 10 cycles respectively. After completing preload treatment, both preloaded rope and strand were tested in five cyclic loadings further at the maximum loading level of 20%MBL in order to examine their stabilities in modulus. The maximum load level of the cyclic loading test for the preloaded rope and strand was set to 20%MBL as this represents typical loading level in practical applications (McKenna etÂ al.,
2004
). The experiment in this study was carried out by using tensile testing machine (AG-I Shimadzu co., maximum load of 100âkN).

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

h3.p:
Table 3.
Preload treatment of the rope and strand.

div.p:
The change in construction geometry of the rope during preload treatment and cyclic loading of the preloaded rope was examined by using a non-contact measurement method which used to detect the change in strand angle and diameter of the rope and it was performed by using high speed camera (Basler ac4600-10uc) with a resolution of 4608âÃâ3288 pixels. The experimental set up of preload treatment and cyclic static loading for both rope and strand are illustrated in
Figure 2
. The rope with the gauge length of 105âmm was sewn at both ends to clamp it to the tensile testing machine (
Figure 2(a)
). For the strand experiment, glass fiber reinforced plastic (GFRP) plates were attached at both ends of the strand with epoxy adhesive (3MScoth-WeldTM DP460) to clamp with grip of tensile testing machine (
Figure 2(b)
). On the other hand, to verify the change in construction geometry of the rope in term of strand angle and rope diameter, acoustic emission (AE) testing was also conducted. Three AE sensors (Physical Acoustics, Type: PICO) were mounted on the rope by using glue (Aron alpha 201) in order to detect AE signals during the test. AE sensors namely S
1
, S
2
and S
3
were mounted at the top, center and bottom of the specimens at the distance of 10, 53 and 95âmm from the top of the rope (
Figure 2(a)
). Sensor S
1
and S
3
were used as guard sensors to distinguish AE from the noises. AE signals larger than 40âdB
AE
were detected and digitized by a digitizer (Physical Acoustic, Type: PCI-2) with a sampling rate of 10âMHz per channel. During the AE testing, AE is detected by each sensor when an event (change in rope construction (friction between strands), noise) occurs. After testing, AE signals measured by each sensor were clustered for each event. AE signals detected during 100 Î¼s from the first measured AE were judged as the same cluster. After clustering, AE signal amplitudes in same cluster were compared to distinguish AE from noise. The AE testing condition of the rope is given in
Table 4
. The strain of ropes and strands in this study were calculated using the crosshead displacement of the tensile testing machine. All ropes and strands were tested at the crosshead speed of 1âmm/min.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

div.p:
Figure 2.
Experimental set up of rope (a) and strand (b) in preload treatment and cyclic static loading.

Figure 2.
Experimental set up of rope (a) and strand (b) in preload treatment and cyclic static loading.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

div.p:
Results of preload treatment of the rope in tensile loading at 20 and 30%MBL are presented in
Figures 3â6
, respectively.
Figure 3
and
5
show the load in %MBL and AE amplitude in dB with respect to the time. AE generated signals at loading part for both preload treatment of the ropes at 20 and 30%MBL since the construction geometry of the ropes were changed in which friction between strands in the ropes occurred. However, after reaching the load levels of 20 and 30%MBL, the loads were hold constant for 3600s in order to stabilize the rope construction geometry and during this period, there were little signals generated by AE which implied that construction geometry of the rope did not change and no further friction between strands took place. Furthermore, it obviously showed that AE generated more signals for preload treatment of rope conducted at 30%MBL comparing to that of 20%MBL because the construction geometry of rope subjected to preload treatment at 30%MBL changed more than that of 20%MBL. To verify the change in construction geometry of the rope with AE results, the change in strand angle and diameter of the rope were measured based on the picture obtained from high speed camera. The change in strand angle and diameter of the rope during preload treatment of the rope at 20 and 30%MBL are presented in
Figure 4
and
6
. The angle and diameter of braided rope decreased drastically during the loading period, however, there were no change in angle and diameter during the constant loading because there was no change in construction geometry of the rope which agrees with the results from AE testing. The results of another preload treatment in cyclic loading at maximum load level of 20%MBL for 10 cycles is shown in
Figure 7
. AE generated signals only at the first cycle since the construction geometry of the rope was changed drastically during this period whereas there was no AE signal for the other cycles because the same loading level was implemented. It is concluded that AE signals were generated as the rope diameter and strand angle changed. It is obviously that the preload treatment in either tensile loading or cyclic loading provide the similar results because AE generated signals in the loading period and the first cycle respectively. Hence, preload treatment in tensile loading could be done as an alternative method of preload treatment in cyclic loading which is commonly utilized in real application.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

Load and AE amplitude of rope during preload treatment in cyclic loading at 20%MBL for 10 cycles.

div.h3: 3.2. Results of cyclic loading of the preloaded rope and strand
div.p:
The preloaded ropes were tested further for five cyclic loadings at maximum load level of 20%MBL in order to check their stabilities in modulus.
Figure 8
shows the results of five cyclic loadings of the preloaded rope in tensile at 20%MBL in which left ordinate axis represents the specific stress (Load/Linear density, N/tex) and right ordinate axis show the amplitude of AE testing. Whereas
Figures 9
and
10
show the change in strand angle and rope diameter in each cycle (cycle 1â5) with respect to strain. Based on these results, the construction geometry of the preloaded rope did not change during the five cyclic loadings because there were almost no AE signals generated compared to that of the rope during loading part of preload treatment as shown in
Figure 3
. Furthermore, the strand angle and diameter of the rope remained almost constant value in each cycle (
Figures 9
and
10
).
Figure 11
shows results of five cyclic loadings of preloaded rope in tensile loading at 20%MBL and the virgin rope at 20%MBL. The strain of preloaded rope was very small compare to that of the virgin rope in which large strain occurred at the first cyclic loading. As a result, the modulus of preloaded rope is higher than that of the virgin rope. The specific modulus of preloaded rope and virgin rope were calculated by fitting the data of specific stress vs. strain. In this study, unloading is omitted when discussing longitudinal elastic modulus because of the buckling effect. The modulus of preloaded rope (cycles 1â5) and virgin rope (cycles 2â5) were determined using the data across the entire range of strain because the specific stress vs. strain are almost perfectly linear. However, the specific modulus of virgin rope at the first cycle could not determine due to strongly nonlinearity of specific stress vs. strain (Sry etÂ al.,
2018
). Since the linear density of the ropes change with length of the rope during cyclic loading which causes to change the modulus of the rope. Therefore, linear density corresponds to each cycle was recalculated when determined the modulus of the rope as well for strand modulus. The moduli of preloaded and virgin ropes at each cycle are given in
Table 5
and represented in
Figure 12
, respectively.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

h3.p:
Table 5.
Specific elastic modulus of preloaded rope and virgin rope.

div.p:
Results show that preload treatment could stabilize the ropes when comparing to the virgin rope, although at the first cycle the moduli of the preloaded ropes are still low compared to the other cycles for all preload treatment cases. McKenna etÂ al. (
2004
) stated that at the first cycle modulus of the stabilized rope is still low compared to the stabilized modulus. These phenomena would come from the change in construction geometry and/or polymeric material used to produce the rope. However, there was no change in construction geometry in term of strand angle and diameter of the preloaded ropes. These results agreed well with AE testing as there were almost no AE signal generated for the preloaded ropes during cyclic loading since the applied load was lessen or equaled to the previous loading that ropes experienced to. Therefore, the viscoelastic of the strand would contribute to the lowest modulus of the preloaded rope. In order to clarify the effect of polymeric material of the rope, the strands that preloaded with the given conditions in
Table 3
were tested in five cyclic loadings at the maximum load level of 20%MBL in same manner as the preloaded ropes. The modulus of preloaded strand was calculated by fitting data of specific stress vs. strain in same procedure as preloaded rope. Moduli of preloaded strands are provided in
Table 6
and
Figure 13
. Results clearly show that the specific moduli of all preloaded strands at the first cycle are lower than the other cycles (cycles 2â5). This phenomenon is caused by material itself in which elastic recovery of polymeric material of the strand after preload treatment would occur because strand is simply made from parallel fibers. Although the moduli of both preloaded strands and ropes at the first cycle are lower than those from the second to fifth cycles, they are virtually stable by comparing to modulus of the first cycle of both virgin strand and rope respectively. In general, the moduli of preloaded ropes and strands become stable from the second cyclic loading onward regardless of preload treatment methods either in tensile loading or cyclic loading. Preload treatment changes the construction geometry of the rope in which it could cancel out the nonlinearity of the rope at the first cyclic loading when the suitable loading is applied. Nonetheless, the full stabilization of the rope modulus could not be achieved because of polymeric material used in the rope in which the elastic recovery would take place during unloading or fully relaxed of the preloaded ropes. Therefore, preload treatment should be performed just prior to applying the rope in real application otherwise instability could occur at the early stage in service. When the rope is utilized at 20%MBL in static application, minimum preload treatment should be carried out at 20%MBL when the utilized load level could be controlled properly in the tendon driven robot. However, when it could not be controlled properly, then higher preload treatment (30%MBL) should be conducted in order to get the stability in elastic modulus of the rope.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

div.p:
Figure 13.
Specific modulus of strands with number of cycles.

Figure 13.
Specific modulus of strands with number of cycles.

div.span: Effect of preload treatment on elastic modulus of braided synthetic fiber rope for static loading

div.div:
V.
Sry
,
D. Y.
Jung
,
Y.
Mizutani
,
G.
Endo
&
A.
Todoroki

h3.p:
Table 6.
Specific elastic modulus of preloaded strand and virgin strand.

div.p: This paper examined different methods of preload treatment in tensile and cyclic loadings, suitable %MBL in preload treatment and clarify the cause of the smallest elastic modulus at the first cycle of the stabilized rope of the HMPE rope. The summarized of conclusions are given as follows:

li.p: Preload treatment in tensile and cyclic loadings yield similar results thus preload treatment in tensile loading could be carried as an alternative preload treatment in cyclic loading which is commonly implemented in real application.

Acoustic emission (AE) testing could be utilized to confirm the change in construction geometry of the rope since AE does not generate the signal if there is no change in rope construction geometry in term of rope diameter and strand angle and vice versa.
Longitudinal elastic modulus of the preloaded rope could not be fully stabilized at the first cycle because of the elastic recovery after preload treatment of the rope.

In tendon driven robot, if the utilized load could be controlled properly then for the rope that is used at 20%MBL, preload treatment could be conducted at 20%MBL. However, if the load could not be controlled properly then preload treatment at 30%MBL should be performed in order to get the stability in rope modulus.
